repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Linematch used to use strchr to navigate a string, however strchr does
not supoprt embedded NULs.

Solution:

Use `mmfile_t` instead of `char*` in linematch and introduce `strnchr()`.

Fixes: #30505

comment_data.body: I don't think using `s->size` here is correct. This is processing the whole file when `matching_chars()` only compares one line.
no need for `register` annotation on variables.
wouldn't `s.ptr++` be matched by `s.size--` ? or am I missing something?
Yes. Good spot. Obviously the test suite isn't exercising this.
How come? I copied this from GCC's `strchr()` implementation, so if they think it's necessary, wouldn't it also be necessary here too?

yes, and when we copy in code into our codebase we adjust it to follow _our_ conventions (which is based on what compilers _we_ support, etc). We don't use `register` annotations in general (because we trust the optimizer with that), and I don't think this function needs to be marked that it came originally from a codebase which uses them.

I compiled this with `gcc` and `clang`. `gcc` with `register` produces the least amount of code.
`gcc` (no `register`) - 28 instructions ``` d10083ff sub sp, sp, #0x20 f9000fe0 str x0, [sp, #0x18] f9000be1 str x1, [sp, #0x10] b9000fe2 str w2, [sp, #0xc] 14000011 b 0x54 f9400fe0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x18] 39c00000 ldrsb w0, [x0] 2a0003e1 mov w1, w0 b9400fe0 ldr w0, [sp, #0xc] 6b01001f cmp w0, w1 54000061 b.ne 0x34 f9400fe0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x18] 1400000e b 0x68 f9400fe0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x18] 91000400 add x0, x0, #0x1 f9000fe0 str x0, [sp, #0x18] f9400be0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x10] b9400000 ldr w0, [x0] 51000401 sub w1, w0, #0x1 f9400be0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x10] b9000001 str w1, [x0] f9400be0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x10] b9400000 ldr w0, [x0] 7100001f cmp w0, #0x0 54fffdac b.gt 0x14 d2800000 mov x0, #0x0 ; =0 910083ff add sp, sp, #0x20 d65f03c0 ret ```
`gcc` (with `register`) - 23 instructions ``` d10043ff sub sp, sp, #0x10 f90007e1 str x1, [sp, #0x8] b90007e2 str w2, [sp, #0x4] 1400000d b 0x40 39c00001 ldrsb w1, [x0] 2a0103e2 mov w2, w1 b94007e1 ldr w1, [sp, #0x4] 6b02003f cmp w1, w2 54000041 b.ne 0x28 1400000c b 0x54 91000400 add x0, x0, #0x1 f94007e1 ldr x1, [sp, #0x8] b9400021 ldr w1, [x1] 51000422 sub w2, w1, #0x1 f94007e1 ldr x1, [sp, #0x8] b9000022 str w2, [x1] f94007e1 ldr x1, [sp, #0x8] b9400021 ldr w1, [x1] 7100003f cmp w1, #0x0 54fffe2c b.gt 0x10 d2800000 mov x0, #0x0 ; =0 910043ff add sp, sp, #0x10 d65f03c0 ret ```
`clang` (with and without `register`) - 34 instructions ``` d10083ff sub sp, sp, #0x20 f9000be0 str x0, [sp, #0x10] f90007e1 str x1, [sp, #0x8] b90007e2 str w2, [sp, #0x4] 14000001 b 0x14 f94007e8 ldr x8, [sp, #0x8] b9400108 ldr w8, [x8] 71000108 subs w8, w8, #0x0 1a9fc7e8 cset w8, le 37000288 tbnz w8, #0x0, 0x74 14000001 b 0x2c f9400be8 ldr x8, [sp, #0x10] 39c00108 ldrsb w8, [x8] b94007e9 ldr w9, [sp, #0x4] 6b090108 subs w8, w8, w9 1a9f07e8 cset w8, ne 370000a8 tbnz w8, #0x0, 0x54 14000001 b 0x48 f9400be8 ldr x8, [sp, #0x10] f9000fe8 str x8, [sp, #0x18] 1400000b b 0x7c f9400be8 ldr x8, [sp, #0x10] 91000508 add x8, x8, #0x1 f9000be8 str x8, [sp, #0x10] f94007e9 ldr x9, [sp, #0x8] b9400128 ldr w8, [x9] 71000508 subs w8, w8, #0x1 b9000128 str w8, [x9] 17ffffe9 b 0x14 f9000fff str xzr, [sp, #0x18] 14000001 b 0x7c f9400fe0 ldr x0, [sp, #0x18] 910083ff add sp, sp, #0x20 d65f03c0 ret ```
With `register`, `gcc` appears to optimize away a couple `ldr` and `str` instructions, which is pretty significant. EDIT: ah, forgot to run with `-O2`. Let me do that.

comment_regular_data.body:
Backport failed for `release-0.10`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.10
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-30526-to-release-0.10 origin/release-0.10
cd .worktree/backport-30526-to-release-0.10
git switch --create backport-30526-to-release-0.10
git cherry-pick -x c65646c2474d22948c604168a68f6626a645d1d2 0fb5299e53cc0d7a5c03c333b1ed79262a0db3f9
```
